content: The Act may be cited as the "Black Metropolis National Heritage Area Study Act". SEC. 4. BLACK METROPOLIS NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA STUDY. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant stakeholders, will conduct a study to determine the feasibility of designating the study area as the Black Metropolis National Heritage Area. The study will analyze if the area has nationally important natural, historic, cultural, educational, scenic, or recreational resources and represents distinctive aspects of the U.S. heritage. The Black Metropolis National Heritage Area study will involve agreements between public and private entities at the local or regional level to manage traditions, customs, beliefs, and folklife that are part of the U.S. heritage. It will also focus on conserving natural, historical, cultural, or scenic features, providing recreational and educational opportunities, and recognizing resources with national importance. Residents, businesses, nonprofits, federal agencies, and state/local/tribal governments in the study area will be involved in the planning process. The study area for the Black Metropolis National Heritage Area has received significant support from residents, businesses, and local and State agencies through letters and other means. SEC. 5. REPORT. The Secretary must submit a report to the House and Senate committees within 3 fiscal years of funds being allocated for this Act, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations from the study.
